text: common mistakes in English lesson 9
topic 2 and enough part 2 using 2 and
enough the bed is too high I need the
bed to be lower luckily I have long legs
my legs are long enough for me to climb
onto this bed be careful with the word
order we place 2 before an adjective or
adverb
for example the bed is too high
but we placed enough after an adjective
or adverb
for example the bed isn't low enough low
enough here are two more examples that
show the correct word order with two I
don't think the mattress was too
expensive when you're looking for a new
mattress don't decide too quickly so in
both sentences you see two placed before
the adjective or adverb alright let's
get a little bit more complex we'll take
it to the next level
it's possible you'll want to give an
explanation following two plus an
adjective look at these three examples
each of them adds more information
following two plus an adjective the bed
is too high for her to climb on the bed
is too high for her the bed is too high
to climb on all three examples are
grammatically correct so you see that we
have three choices when you give an
explanation the explanation can take the
form of for whom and it can take the
form of an infinitive
please be careful you've probably seen
the word 2 written at the end of a
sentence or the end of a clause that
structure has a different meaning it has
nothing to do with an amount it has
everything to do with agreement to
written at the end of a sentence means
also for example my husband likes the
mattress and I do too I also like it
let's turn our attention now to enough I
said that enough follows an adjective or
adverb look at these two examples I'm
tall enough to climb on we've been
sleeping well enough to convince us that
the mattress was a good purchase in both
cases you see enough following an
adjective or adverb enough can also
follow a verb look at these two examples
if you search enough you'll find a good
product we didn't look at every mattress
in the store but we saw enough to
convince us that our final choice was a
good one in both sentences we use the
structure verb plus enough but I'd like
you to understand that enough is working
differently in each sentence in the
first it's an adverb
it answers the question how or how much
did you search if you search enough in
the second sentence enough is a pronoun
it answers the question what enough is
the object of saw what did you see we
saw enough enough refers to enough
mattresses
as with two enough can be followed by an
explanation look at these three examples
in which an adjective plus enough is
followed by some form of explanation the
price was low enough for us to purchase
the mattress the price was low enough
for us the price was low enough to make
us seriously consider the purchase so
just as with to the explanation can take
the form of for whom or an infinitive or
you might have both as in the first
example take a moment to review all
three examples
all right
before we go on let's quickly review the
uses of enough that we've seen so far we
know that enough can follow an adjective
as in tall enough
we know that enough can follow an adverb
as in quickly enough and we've seen how
enough can follow a verb and when it
follows a verb it can be either an
adverb or a pronoun answering the
questions how or what examples would be
if you searched enough you'll find what
you want and we didn't see a lot of
mattresses but we saw enough to make our
selection now I'd like to show you one
more use of enough so far you've seen
the word order where enough follows an
adjective and adverb or a verb it's
possible for enough to come before a
noun it still has the same meaning which
is the amount that you want or the
amount that is needed it's simply a
different word order so when we use
enough with a noun usually it comes
before the noun study this example with
me the store gives customers a 30-day
trial with any mattress that should be
enough time to decide if one likes a
mattress or not it was enough time for
us here we see enough placed before the
noun time and as we saw with other
structures we can add an explanation in
the form of an infinitive or for whom
enough time to decide enough time for us
are you ready for another exercise
exercise to find the mistake and correct
it number one
our old mattress wasn't enough firm we
needed a mattress that gave better back
support do you see the mistake
enough firm has the wrong word order we
need to say firm enough
to our old mattress was lumpy and you
could feel the springs inside we wanted
a more comfortable mattress one that
would be soft enough for to get a good
night's rest do you see the mistake
it's here remember the explanation
following enough can either be in the
form of for whom or an infinitive so
there are two ways to correct this we
could write soft enough for us to get a
good night's rest or simply soft enough
to get a good night's rest
three we didn't want a mattress that was
too cheap nor did we want one that cost
as much as a car we had money enough to
buy a mattress of good quality do you
see the mistake it's not so much a
mistake as it is awkward wording
it's here sometimes a noun can come
before enough but usually it sounds more
natural to place the noun after so I
would change the sentence to read we had
enough money to buy a mattress of good
quality
for I worried that the delivery men
wouldn't be able to get the new mattress
up the narrow stairs
I thought the mattress wouldn't be too
wide I was wrong and they got it up just
fine do you see the mistake
look closely
the mistake is here remember to buy
itself has a negative meaning and when
we put it together with a negative verb
the meaning changes the sentence as it
is written doesn't make sense to correct
it we must change wouldn't be - would be
I thought the mattress would be too wide
five some may say our mattress very cost
too much but we believe we paid for
quality and we got it do you see the
mistake it's here we have one word too
many don't we both words very and two
can strengthen a word intensify a
meaning you can see very much as a
phrase and too much as a phrase but we'd
never put very and two together in the
sentence I'm trying to explain that some
people might feel we paid more than we
should have more than what was needed so
the better word here is to some may say
our mattress cost too much in this last
part of our lesson I'd like to share
some conversational uses of too and
enough I told you that we can't put very
and two together but there are other
words that help us intensify to way too
and all to have the meaning of much too
for example the bed is way too high
these kinds of mistakes happen all too
often these are very conversational
sentences here are two conversational
uses of enough we say strangely enough
or oddly enough to comment on a
surprising situation for example
oddly enough the manager thought the
mistake was funny we use sure enough to
comment on an event that happened as
expected
meaning as we thought it would for
example sure enough the store
acknowledged its mistake and gave the
customer a refund
here are two more common conversational
uses of enough you might say enough is
enough to express your anger with a
situation because you think it should
stop you might say stop arguing enough
is enough
can't get enough of something or if
someone means you want more and more of
it because you really enjoy it for
example I can't get enough of your love
let's do one more exercise
exercise three answer the questions try
to use two and enough in your answers
one oddly enough some people prefer the
floor to a bed how about you is the
floor comfortable enough for you to
sleep on
- all too often stores make mistakes and
customers must deal with the
consequences describe a time you paid
for the mistake made by a store or other
business
three sometimes I love a song so much I
can't get enough of it I play it over
and over again what song do you love
enough to listen at least five or ten
times in one day
for was there a subject in school you
found way too easy did you ever have a
teacher who knew how to challenge you
enough to make learning interesting
without making it too difficult
five do you feel you have enough time to
study English do you think you spend too
much time too little time or enough time
on your studies
